thm kur14lem1(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4) {
  |- wi(wceq(c0, c1), wa(wss(c0, c2), wss(cpr(cdif(c2, c0), cfv(c3, c0)), c4)))
  -| wss(c1, c2)
  -| wcel(cdif(c2, c1), c4)
  -| wcel(cfv(c3, c1), c4)
} = {
  jca(wceq(c0, c1), wss(c0, c2), wss(cpr(cdif(c2, c0), cfv(c3, c0)), c4))
  mpbiri(wceq(c0, c1), wss(c0, c2), wss(c1, c2))
  sseq1(c0, c1, c2)
  syl6eqss(cpr(cdif(c2, c0), cfv(c3, c0)), c4, cpr(cdif(c2, c1), cfv(c3, c1)), wceq(c0, c1))
  preq12d(cdif(c2, c0), cfv(c3, c0), cdif(c2, c1), cfv(c3, c1), wceq(c0, c1))
  difeq2(c0, c1, c2)
  fveq2(c0, c1, c3)
  mp2an(wss(cpr(cdif(c2, c1), cfv(c3, c1)), c4), wcel(cdif(c2, c1), c4), wcel(cfv(c3, c1), c4))
  prssi(cdif(c2, c1), c4, cfv(c3, c1))
}

blocks.name: kur14lem2
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ kur14 . Write interior in terms of closure and complement: ` i A = c k c A ` where ` c ` is complement and ` k ` is closure. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 11-Feb-2015.)
blocks.origin:
thm kur14lem2(class c0, class c1, class c2, class c3, class c4) {
  |- wceq(cfv(c0, c1), cdif(c2, cfv(c3, cdif(c2, c1))))
  -| wcel(c4, ctop)
  -| wceq(c2, cuni(c4))
  -| wceq(c3, cfv(ccl, c4))
  -| wceq(c0, cfv(cnt, c4))
  -| wss(c1, c2)
} = {
  3eqtr4i(cfv(c0, c1), cdif(c2, cfv(c3, cdif(c2, c1))), cfv(cfv(cnt, c4), c1), cdif(c2, cfv(cfv(ccl, c4), cdif(c2, c1))))
  mp2an(wceq(cfv(cfv(cnt, c4), c1), cdif(c2, cfv(cfv(ccl, c4), cdif(c2, c1)))), wcel(c4, ctop), wss(c1, c2))
  ntrval2(c4, c1, c2)
  fveq1i(c0, c1, cfv(cnt, c4))
  difeq2i(c2, cfv(c3, cdif(c2, c1)), cfv(cfv(ccl, c4), cdif(c2, c1)))
  fveq1i(c3, cdif(c2, c1), cfv(ccl, c4))

  ⊢ (c0 ` c1)=(c2 \(c3 `(c2 \ c1)))

  ⊣ c2 = ⋃ c4

blocks.name: kur14lem3
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ kur14 . A closure is a subset of the base set. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 11-Feb-2015.)

  -| wcel(c3, ctop)
  -| wceq(c2, cuni(c3))
  -| wceq(c0, cfv(ccl, c3))
  -| wceq(c4, cfv(cnt, c3))

} = {
  a1ii(wss(cfv(c0, c1), c2), wceq(c4, cfv(cnt, c3)))
  eqsstri(cfv(c0, c1), c2, cfv(cfv(ccl, c3), c1))
  fveq1i(c0, c1, cfv(ccl, c3))
  mp2an(wss(cfv(cfv(ccl, c3), c1), c2), wcel(c3, ctop), wss(c1, c2))

blocks.name: kur14lem4
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ kur14 . Complementation is an involution on the set of subsets of a topology. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 11-Feb-2015.)
blocks.origin:

  dfss4(c1, c0)

blocks.content: Lemma for ~ kur14 . Closure is an idempotent operation in the set of subsets of a topology. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 11-Feb-2015.)

  clsidm(c2, c1, c3)

blocks.name: kur14lem6
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ kur14 . If ` k ` is the complementation operator and ` k ` is the closure operator, this expresses the identity ` k c k A = k c k c k c k A ` for any subset ` A ` of the topological space. This is the key result that lets us cut down long enough sequences of ` c k c k ... ` that arise when applying closure and complement repeatedly to ` A ` , and explains why we end up with a number as large as ` 1 4 ` , yet no larger. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 11-Feb-2015.)

  -| wceq(c2, cdif(c4, cfv(c0, c5)))

  eqssi(cfv(c0, cfv(c1, cfv(c0, c2))), cfv(c0, c2))
  sseqtri(cfv(c0, cfv(c1, cfv(c0, c2))), cfv(c0, c2), cfv(c0, cfv(c0, c2)))

  mp2an(wss(cfv(cfv(cnt, c3), cfv(c0, c2)), cfv(c0, c2)), wcel(c3, ctop), wss(cfv(c0, c2), c4))

  eqsstri(cfv(c1, cfv(c0, c2)), c4, cdif(c4, cfv(c0, cdif(c4, cfv(c0, c2)))))

blocks.name: kur14lem7
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ kur14 : main proof. The set ` T ` here contains all the distinct combinations of ` k ` and ` c ` that can arise, and we prove here that applying ` k ` or ` c ` to any element of ` T ` yields another elemnt of ` T ` . In operator shorthand, we have ` T = { A , c A , k A ` ` , c k A , k c A , c k c A , k c k A , c k c k A , k c k c A , ` ` c k c k c A , k c k c k A , c k c k c k A , k c k c k c A , ` ` c k c k c k c A } ` . From the identities ` c c A = A ` and ` k k A = k A ` , we can reduce any operator combination containing two adjacent identical operators, which is why the list only contains alternating sequences. The reason the sequences don't keep going after a certain point is due to the identity ` k c k A = k c k c k c k A ` , proved in ~ kur14lem6 . (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 11-Feb-2015.)

blocks.name: kur14lem8
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ kur14 . Show that the set ` T ` contains at most ` 1 4 ` elements. (It could be less if some of the operators take the same value for a given set, but Kuratowski showed that this upper bound of ` 1 4 ` is tight in the sense that there exist topological spaces and subsets of these spaces for which all ` 1 4 ` generated sets are distinct, and indeed the real numbers form such a topological space.) (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 11-Feb-2015.)

blocks.name: kur14lem9
blocks.content: Lemma for ~ kur14 . Since the set ` T ` is closed under closure and complement, it contains the minimal set ` S ` as a subset, so ` S ` also has at most ` 1 4 ` elements. (Indeed ` S = T ` , and it's not hard to prove this, but we don't need it for this proof.) (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 11-Feb-2015.)

blocks.name: kur14
blocks.content: Kuratowski's closure-complement theorem. There are at most 14 sets which can be obtained by the application of the closure and complement operations to a set in a topological space. (Contributed by Mario Carneiro, 11-Feb-2015.)
